poem:
### Against Touristification

In sun-drenched squares where shadows  
measure the hours, voices rise—  
the bricks ache under footsteps not their own;  
crossing terraces,  
narrow streets,  
the tide of being known  
erodes native ground.  
    
Here, stillness.  
Among shuttered homes, a whisper—  
let us be more  
than postcard dreams.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Campaigners mount coordinated protests across Europe against ‘touristification’ Campaigners in at least a dozen tourist hotspots across southern Europe have taken to the streets to protest against “touristification”. It is the most widespread joint action to date against what they see as the steady reshaping of their cities to meet the needs of tourists rather than people who live and work there. Thousands turned out at marches in cities including Barcelona and Palma de Mallorca". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
